text:
I have an Apache server running in Spain. This weekend, we had an automatic 
change of hour, (during the nigth from saturday to sunday, we change the clock, 
at three , it changed to 2).

I have made a test, and if I make a request of a resource, and I get the 
hearder field "Last-Modified" I get different values depending on the date. If 
it is 10-30-2004 I get the value 1097145414000.And if it is 02-11-2004, I get 
1097149014000 (diferent in 3600000, one hour)
creator: eu_jls@yahoo.es

text:
Apache doesn't send milliseconds, it sends a human readable HTTP date. What are
the exact headers and what's the problem with them?
creator: nd@perlig.de

text:
Sorry, I showed the results from our Java application that works with the "Last-
Modified" hearder field in "java long" format. If I present them as they 
return, I get this values.

"Thu, 07 Oct 2004 11:36:54 GMT" (server System clock in november)
"Thu, 07 Oct 2004 10:36:54 GMT" (server System clock before the 30 of october)
creator: eu_jls@yahoo.es

text:
Well, after some starring on the dates, I've understood the problem ;-)
Confirmation question: Is the file stored on a FAT volume?
creator: nd@perlig.de
wrowe@apache.org
text:
This certainly sounds a well-documented flaw in the FAT file system.

NTFS filesystem dates should be stored in utc.

Certainly the server has FAT32 file system. 
 
My question now is if I can expect this problem be solved in the future. 
 
Searching the web, I have found code samples that are supposed to solve this 
problem, like the one that is in this link 
 
http://www.codeproject.com/datetime/dstbugs.asp
creator: eu_jls@yahoo.es
nick@webthing.com
text:
This seems to be a filesystem bug, not an apache one.  And in any case,
mod_headers has nothing to do with last-modified.
